bestBHT.bht: They compelled a man named Simon of Cyrene to bear His cross, sweet compulsion if it resulted in him or his sons voluntarily taking up their cross! After Jesus was initially unable to proceed due to exhaustion, the burden of the cross was laid on Simon to bear it after Him. The soldiers showed no hesitation in taking hold of anyone to help carry the cross. Simon's involvement was a significant opportunity to participate in the suffering of Christ, even though he likely bore the hinder part of the cross.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: He was 'the father of Alexander and Rufus,' probably better known afterwards than himself, as disciples."
Him they compel to bear His cross, sweet compulsion, if it issued in him or his sons voluntarily 'taking up their cross!'
It would appear that our Lord had first to bear His own cross, but being from exhaustion unable to proceed, it was laid on another to bear it 'after Him.'
Albert Barnes: After Jesus - Probably to bear one end of the cross."
Jesus was feeble and unable to bear it alone, and they compelled Simon to help him."
They compelled Simon to help him.
Marvin Vincent: Laid hold on [επιλαβομενοι] . Compare the peculiar word used by Matthew and Mark. See on Matthew 5:41.
- 32. Peculiar to Luke. See Introduction, on the gospel of womanhood.
Philip Schaff: The relief was comparatively slight; there is no proof that our Lord was sinking under the load.
He who bears the cross after Jesus, bears the lightest end of it.
The hinder part alone was laid upon Simon.
Archibald T. Robertson: The soldiers had no scruples about taking hold of any one of themselves.
To bear it, to go on bearing.
John Gill: After they had finished their sport and pastime with him, and had put on him his own clothes again.
Perhaps knew nothing of the matter, what had been doing at Jerusalem.
They put the cross, at least one end of it, upon this man's shoulders.

bhtAttempts.bht: They compelled a man named Simon of Cyrene to bear His cross, a task that seems to connect with the idea of disciples taking up their cross. Although Jesus initially carried His own cross, He eventually became too exhausted and another was asked to bear it after Him. It is interesting to note that the soldiers who laid hold of Simon had no qualms about taking anyone to help carry the cross. Simon's involvement in this act of bearing the cross was a sweet compulsion - an opportunity to participate in the suffering of Christ. While Simon was likely burdened with the hinder part of the cross, this task served as a significant moment in the journey to the crucifixion.

They compelled a man named Simon of Cyrene to bear His cross, sweet compulsion if it resulted in him or his sons voluntarily taking up their cross! After Jesus was initially unable to proceed due to exhaustion, the burden of the cross was laid on Simon to bear it after Him. The soldiers showed no hesitation in taking hold of anyone to help carry the cross. Simon's involvement was a significant opportunity to participate in the suffering of Christ, even though he likely bore the hinder part of the cross.

After Jesus became too exhausted to carry His own cross, a man named Simon of Cyrene was compelled to bear it after Him. This act of burden-sharing allowed Simon and his sons to participate in the discipleship of carrying their own crosses. The soldiers showed no scruples about taking hold of any available person to assist. Simon's involvement provided a poignant reminder that those who bear the cross after Jesus bear the lightest end of it.

They compelled a man named Simon of Cyrene to bear the cross after Jesus became too exhausted to continue. The soldiers had no scruples about taking hold of any one of themselves to help with this task. Simon's involvement in carrying the cross allowed him and his sons to participate in discipleship, taking up their own crosses. This act of burden-sharing was a sweet compulsion, offering an opportunity for others to bear the lightest end of the cross after Jesus.

They compelled a man named Simon of Cyrene to bear His cross after Jesus became too exhausted to proceed. This act of burden-sharing allowed Simon and his sons to participate in the discipleship of carrying their own crosses. The soldiers had no qualms about taking hold of anyone to help with this task. This sweet compulsion provided an opportunity for others to bear the lightest end of the cross after Jesus.
